It‚Äôs this generosity and care for one another that gives me hope that America‚Äôs best days are still yet to come, and makes me so proud to call these great United States home.
Let‚Äôs not forget that Americans are generous with their time too: in 2019 three in ten American adults volunteered for an awe-inspiring total of 5.8 billion hours, according to AmeriCorps.

Generosity across generations shows the tradition is still going strong.

84% of millennials, 72% of baby boomers, and 88% of the silent generation give to charity.

https://www.definefinancial.com/blog/charitable-giving-statistics/

Everyone gives according to their means.

In fact, households making less than $50,000 a year give more to charity, as a share of their income, than any income bracket except those making over $10 million.

https://www.definefinancial.com/blog/charitable-giving-statistics/

Traditionally the winter holiday season is primetime for giving.

One-fifth of non-profit revenue is raised in December, and half of that is in the last three days of the month!

https://neonone.com/resources/blog/year-end-giving-statistics/

Last year alone Americans gave $485 billion to nonprofits, with two-thirds coming from individual donations. 

60% of U.S. households give to charity in a typical year.

https://www.nptrust.org/philanthropic-resources/charitable-giving-statistics/

It‚Äôs so inspiring to see that Americans turn to their faith to step up and help those less fortunate.

Despite what you may hear in the media, our faith is what drives us forward as a country, and as a community.

Philanthropy Roundtable credits our unique history & character, including strong social consciousness and spiritual faith.

https://www.definefinancial.com/blog/charitable-giving-statistics/

Despite many American families struggling, generosity still defines us.

Americans give 7x as much as Europeans and 2x as much as Canadians per capita.
